questions.text: What is the main character in a story called?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The setting of a story tells when and where it takes place.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What part of the story tells how the problem is solved?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each story element to its definition.

rightItems: The people or animals in the story
Where and when the story happens

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A fable usually teaches a lesson or moral.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which word describes how a character feels?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put these story events in the correct order.

draggableItems: The boy finds his lost dog
The boy looks everywhere
The boy loses his dog

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What do we call the problem in a story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Poetry is written in sentences and paragraphs just like regular stories.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Poetry is written in lines and stanzas, which is different from prose.

questions.text: Match each story type to its description.

rightItems: Has magic and often begins 'Once upon a time'
A short story with animals that teaches a lesson
A traditional story passed down through generations

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Who writes a story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The illustrator draws the pictures in a book.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In a story, a girl helps a lost kitten find its home. What is the central message of this story?

choices: It is good to help others
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It is good to help others

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The central message is the main lesson or idea the story teaches. Helping others is the theme shown through the girl's actions.

questions.text: A story has a beginning, middle, and end.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Pictures in a book can help you understand what is happening in the story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What question can help you find a key detail in a story?

choices: What is the book made of?

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match the character trait to its meaning.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Sam was scared of the dark. One night, he heard a noise and went to look. He found it was just his cat. Now Sam is not so scared anymore. What is the beginning of this story?

choices: Sam was scared of the dark
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Sam was scared of the dark

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When a story uses the word 'I' to tell what happens, who is telling the story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: When a story uses 'I', it is told from first-person point of view, meaning a character in the story is the narrator.

questions.text: Put the events from 'The Tortoise and the Hare' in order.

draggableItems: The tortoise wins the race
The hare takes a nap
The hare and tortoise start a race

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In the story 'The Three Little Pigs,' what major event happens to the first two houses?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A character in a story is always a person.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Characters can be people, animals, or even objects that act like people in a story.

questions.text: What does an illustration show in a story?

choices: A picture of what is happening
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A picture of what is happening

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each question word to the type of detail it helps you find.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Maria shared her lunch with a new student who forgot hers. What does this tell us about Maria?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In a story, the picture shows a boy with tears on his face. How does the boy probably feel?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the lesson a story teaches called?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put the parts of a story in order.

draggableItems: End - The problem is solved
Beginning - Characters are introduced
Middle - The problem happens

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The central message of a story is the same as the main idea.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A lion let a mouse go free. Later, the mouse helped the lion escape from a net. What is the moral of this fable?

choices: Even small friends can be a big help
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Even small friends can be a big help

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: This is Aesop's fable 'The Lion and the Mouse.' The moral teaches that no act of kindness is wasted and even small creatures can help in big ways.

questions.text: Match the feeling word to what a character might do.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: If a story says 'Long ago in a faraway kingdom,' what does this tell us?

choices: When and where the story happens
questionOptions.correctAnswer: When and where the story happens

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Tom wanted to win the race. He practiced every day. On race day, he ran his fastest and won! What is the middle of this story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When you retell a story, you tell it again in your own words.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Different characters in a story can have different points of view about the same event.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Characters may see the same event differently based on their own feelings and experiences.

questions.text: In the story, the picture shows children building a snowman. What season is it probably in the story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each story element with an example.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which question would help you understand a character better?

choices: How many pages is the book?
Why did the character do that?
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Why did the character do that?

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A crow was thirsty but could not reach the water in a tall jar. The crow dropped pebbles into the jar until the water rose high enough to drink. What does this fable teach?

choices: Thinking and trying can solve problems
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Thinking and trying can solve problems

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: This is Aesop's fable 'The Crow and the Pitcher.' The moral is about using your brain to solve problems.

questions.text: Put these events from 'Goldilocks and the Three Bears' in order.

draggableItems: The bears come home and find Goldilocks
Goldilocks tries three chairs
Goldilocks enters the bears' house

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Anna wanted her friend's toy, so she took it without asking. Later, Anna felt bad and gave it back with an apology. How did Anna change from the beginning to the end of the story?

choices: She learned to do the right thing
questionOptions.correctAnswer: She learned to do the right thing

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The narrator is always a character in the story.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Sometimes the narrator is a character (first person), but other times the narrator is outside the story (third person).

questions.text: Match the part of the story to what happens there.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Read this passage: 'I walked into the dark cave. My heart was beating fast. I heard strange sounds.' Who is telling this story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The use of 'I' tells us this is first-person narration, where a character in the story is telling what happened.

questions.text: In the story, the illustration shows a character with crossed arms and a frown. The text says 'Mom said it was time for bed.' How does the illustration help you understand the story?

choices: It shows what time it is
It shows the character is unhappy about bedtime
It shows what the bedroom looks like
It shows who the mom is
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It shows the character is unhappy about bedtime

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An ant worked hard all summer to store food. A grasshopper played all summer and had no food for winter. What is the central message of this fable?

choices: Playing is more fun than working
It is important to plan ahead
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It is important to plan ahead

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: This is Aesop's fable 'The Ant and the Grasshopper.' The moral teaches the importance of hard work and planning for the future.

questions.text: Put these events in order to retell 'Little Red Riding Hood.'

draggableItems: The wolf pretends to be grandma
Little Red Riding Hood walks through the forest
The hunter saves grandma and Little Red Riding Hood

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In a story, Ben thinks the new student is unfriendly. Later, Ben learns the new student was just shy. How does Ben's point of view change?

choices: Ben thinks the student is more unfriendly
Ben stops talking to the student
Ben's point of view stays the same

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Ben's point of view changes when he learns new information about the student. He goes from thinking the student is unfriendly to understanding the student is shy.

questions.text: Match each illustration description to what it tells the reader.

leftItems: Picture of rain outside a window
Picture of a character with a big smile

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A boy found a magic lamp. He made three wishes but was still not happy. Then he realized his family and friends made him happier than any wish. Compare the beginning and end of this story. How did the character's understanding change?

choices: He learned magic is not real
He learned that wishes cannot come true
He learned that happiness comes from people we love, not things
He learned to make better wishes
questionOptions.correctAnswer: He learned that happiness comes from people we love, not things

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The central message is about what truly makes us happy. The character changes from thinking wishes will make him happy to understanding that relationships are more valuable.

questions.text: What is a story called that is passed down from parents to children over many years?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A poem often has words that rhyme.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Who is the person that reads the story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Stories only happen in real places.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Stories can happen in made-up or imaginary places too.

questions.text: The title of a book is found on the cover.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What do we call the people or animals in a story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each book part to what it does.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put these actions in order to show how to read a book.

draggableItems: Close the book when finished
Open the book
Read the pages from start to end

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the first thing that happens in a story called?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Jake saw a puppy in the rain. He brought the puppy inside and dried it off. What kind of person is Jake?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Where does the story 'Cinderella' mostly take place?

choices: At a palace and her home
questionOptions.correctAnswer: At a palace and her home

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Asking 'What happened first?' helps you understand the order of events.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match the feeling to the face.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In a story, Amy's dog runs away. She looks all over the neighborhood. Finally, she finds him at the park. What is the end of this story?

choices: Amy finds her dog at the park
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Amy finds her dog at the park

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put these events from 'Jack and the Beanstalk' in order.

draggableItems: Jack climbs the beanstalk
Jack trades the cow for magic beans
Jack escapes from the giant

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The illustration shows a boy holding a trophy and smiling. How does the boy feel?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each character action to the feeling it shows.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Every story has at least one character.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A story about a talking bear is an example of what?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A dog named Max got lost. His owner called his name. Max heard and ran home. What is the problem in this story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In a story, a girl named Mia does not want to share her toys. By the end, she learns sharing makes her happy. What is the lesson?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each word to what it describes in a story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Read this passage: 'Emma looked at the dark sky. She heard thunder. She ran inside.' What can you tell about the weather?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the solution in a story?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put these events in order to make a story.

draggableItems: Lily finds her lost cat under the porch
Lily notices her cat is missing
Lily looks around the yard calling for her cat

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The author and illustrator of a book can be the same person.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In the story, Leo is afraid to swim. His friend shows him how to float. Then Leo tries and finds out it is fun. How did Leo change?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of story to its example.

rightItems: A story with a princess and magic
A short story where animals talk and teach a lesson

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In a poem, the words 'cat' and 'hat' are an example of what?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Illustrations can show things that the words do not tell us.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A boy was jealous of his sister's new bike. He worked hard doing chores and saved money to buy his own bike. Now he is proud. What is the central message?

choices: Hard work helps you get what you want
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Hard work helps you get what you want

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In the fable, a fox could not reach grapes on a vine. He said, 'Those grapes are probably sour anyway.' What does this teach us?

choices: Sometimes we pretend we do not want what we cannot have
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Sometimes we pretend we do not want what we cannot have

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: This is Aesop's fable 'The Fox and the Grapes.' The moral teaches about making excuses when we cannot get what we want.

questions.text: Match the story element to its example from 'Snow White.'

rightItems: The evil queen wants to hurt Snow White
Snow White, the queen, the prince

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Two friends, Maya and Rosa, see a stray dog. Maya wants to take it home. Rosa thinks they should find its owner first. How are their points of view different?

choices: Maya wants to keep the dog; Rosa wants to find its real owner
They both want to ignore the dog
They both want to call the police
Maya is scared; Rosa is happy
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Maya wants to keep the dog; Rosa wants to find its real owner

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put these story events in order to show how a character changes.

draggableItems: Tim says sorry and becomes friends with the new kid
Tim makes fun of a new kid at school
Tim feels bad when he sees the kid sitting alone

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The illustration shows a girl standing on stage with a microphone. The audience is clapping. What is probably happening?
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Characters can have more than one feeling at the same time.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: A character can feel excited and scared at the same time, for example.

questions.text: Match how the character feels at different parts of the story.

leftItems: Beginning: Sara moves to a new school
Middle: Sara has no one to eat lunch with
End: Sara makes a new friend

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In a story, a wolf dressed as a sheep to trick the shepherd. The other sheep knew something was wrong. How did the sheep and shepherd see the wolf differently?

choices: The shepherd was fooled; the sheep were not
Everyone knew it was a wolf
The sheep were fooled; the shepherd was not
No one could tell the difference
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The shepherd was fooled; the sheep were not

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A story can have more than one lesson or central message.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A shepherd boy cried 'Wolf!' when there was no wolf, just to see the villagers run. When a real wolf came, no one believed him. What lessons does this teach?

choices: Liars are not believed even when they tell the truth
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Liars are not believed even when they tell the truth

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: This is Aesop's fable 'The Boy Who Cried Wolf.' It teaches that if you lie, people will stop trusting you.

questions.text: In a story, Kai is new at school. Everyone ignores him. Then Kai helps the class win a game, and everyone wants to be his friend. Compare how others treated Kai at the beginning and end of the story.

choices: At first ignored, then included and liked
questionOptions.correctAnswer: At first ignored, then included and liked

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match the beginning of the story to how it connects to the end.

leftItems: Beginning: Ella is afraid to try new foods
Beginning: A bird cannot fly because of a hurt wing
rightItems: End: The brothers learn to work together to solve a problem
End: Ella discovers she loves trying new foods
End: The bird's wing heals and it flies away

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put these events in order to show how a problem is solved in the story.

draggableItems: The class raises money and buys books for the library
The school library has no new books
Students decide to have a bake sale to help

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In the story, a grandmother tells a tale to her grandson. The grandson is listening. What are the different voices telling the story called?

choices: Different points of view or perspectives
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Different points of view or perspectives

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In the story, the text says 'The room was quiet.' The illustration shows broken toys everywhere. What extra information does the picture give?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The illustration adds information by showing that something (perhaps a mess or accident) happened, even though the text only mentions quietness.

questions.text: Two versions of Cinderella are from different countries. In one, she has a fairy godmother. In another, a magical fish helps her. What is the same in both?

choices: A kind girl gets help and goes to a ball
They happen in the same country
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A kind girl gets help and goes to a ball

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Different versions of the same story can have the same basic plot but different details.

questions.text: Reading the words and looking at the pictures together helps you understand a story better.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match the question to what it helps you understand.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A story can teach us something even if it has imaginary characters like dragons or talking animals.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Fables and fantasy stories often teach important lessons through imaginary characters and events.
